Yes, the Visigoths had religious practices and beliefs unique to their culture. Before converting to Catholicism, the Visigoths were Arian Christians and had different beliefs from Catholics. Arianism was a Christian heresy that rejected the doctrine of the Trinity, which Catholics believed in. The Visigoths believed that God the Father created the son, Jesus Christ, who was inferior to him.

Additionally, the Visigoths had unique burial practices that reflected their culture and beliefs. Visigothic tombs often contained personal property and weapons, which they believed would accompany the deceased into the afterlife. They also believed in the concept of the afterlife and thought that the soul continued to exist even after death.

Visigothic society also valued physical strength and prowess in battle. As a result, they revered powerful gods, including Thor and Odin. The Visigoths believed that these gods would grant them strength in battle and protection, making them invincible on the battlefield.

Another unique aspect of Visigothic culture was the use of runic alphabets. Runic inscriptions have been found on Visigothic objects, which suggest that they used runic alphabets for magical and religious purposes, as well as for writing.

Overall, the Visigoths had unique religious beliefs and practices that were a product of their culture and heritage. While they later adopted Catholicism, their religious practices and beliefs were an important part of their society and history.
